Describe a time you felt unprepared to make a financial decision.
answers: when I had unexpected spending, such as buying a new card
Buying a home for the first time was very uncertain because of my lack of knowledge. Only after having done it I can be more confident when I do it again in the future

When I had to find an apartment the first time and budget not only rent, utilities, and other expenses that where not obvious at first. I knew about rent, and water electric, etc. but didn't think of trash, sewer, other fees and didn't ask some the places I toured until I understood more.

I currently feel unprepared to invest in the stock market. I'm not sure what to invest in and when I ask everyone says the market might crash and nothing is certain right now. I'm just confused overall.
Its getting better, but I have always felt a little overwhelmed trying to make big financial decisions.

text: Final Thoughts: If you could design a financial-learning app for people your age, what would it include? Describe any features, challenges, or rewards you would want to see.
answers: At my age it could be helpful to know where you stand with saving and where you need to be. That can help ease anxiety for people who feel behind. And it can help encourage people who aren't saving to save more.

I'd like something the lets me set only set large goals like home loans, but also small goals like weekly movie night etc. It would also be nice to have an app that teaches about the different unexpected fees one might need to pay and how to plan for those like car repairs or new work computers, etc.

A neat feature I see a lot is having integration that makes cancelling subscriptions easier. These days I have very few, but I know some people who struggle and likely don’t realize how much they’re spending on these apps.
Investment strategies separated by risk and reward. This would give recommendations that are high risk/ high reward and low risk/ low reward.
it would include a system that took inputs of my earning details, took my savings details, monitored my expenses and them made suggestions on what could be fixed, the mistakes i make etc.

I'd want an app with personalized scenarios based on my actual financial situation, interactive simulations for major decisions like buying a car or investing, clear visualizations of long-term impact of decisions, integration with my real accounts for practical tracking, and bite-sized lessons I can complete in 5-10 minutes. It should feel less like homework and more like a helpful assistant guiding me through real financial challenges.
Visual graphs and easy user interface
Savings goals, progress towards that, projected net worth, allocation between various accounts, credit card spending
gamified ideas are nice; perhaps an rpg game where it's easy to see how big purchases hurt your savings in the long run
help them understand their options for investments
I would include possible alternative routes and warnings about potential issues that most young people get trapped into.
